content_metadata.title: Marine Corps Vocalist Video Analysis

trimmingSuggestions.description: The image montage, while visually appealing, could be shortened slightly to maintain a brisk pace. Consider selecting the most impactful images that showcase LCpl Browning's diverse performance experience.
Condense LCpl Browning's explanation of the training curriculum to focus on the key aspects that are unique to the Marine Corps.

text_to_speech: [Music] Lance Corporal Megan browning and I am a vocalist in the United States Marine Corps as a Marine Corps vocalist we are there to engage an audience and represent the Marine Corps I've been singing for a very long time I think my first ever solo was in fifth grade [Music] I started professionally singing at 17 and I worked at Busch Gardens it was super fun and then I caught the bug as they say but going contract to contract like that light as a civilian musician was not what it was all cracked up to be as you get older gets a little scarier because you're like oh I have this dream and then you're like oh let's make this a reality since I've been here I've been very grateful that there's been a solidified plan of what I'm gonna be doing I take vocal lessons from an Army sergeant first class don't read there okay breathe there God shed His grace on me [Music] and then my curriculum is kind of built off of the Navy vocalist curriculum with a few adjustments that are tailored to ring for life and what the Marine Corps band will actually need from a fleet vocalist I'm so excited to help grow this MOS I'm excited that more people are finding out about it and that more people are gonna come in and make this whole group that I get to work with gonna be really excited when this grows and solidifies itself [Music]

timecoded_text_to_speech.text: Lance Corporal Megan Browning and I am a vocalist in the United States Marine Corps.
As a Marine Corps vocalist, we are there to engage in audience and represent the Marine Corps.
I've been singing for a very long time. I think my first ever solo was in fifth grade.
I think my first ever solo was in fifth grade.
I started professionally singing at 17 and I worked at Bush Gardens. It was super fun.
And then I caught the bug as they say. But going contract to contract like that,
like as a civilian musician, was not what it was all cracked up to be.
As you get older, it gets a little scarier because you're like, oh, I have this dream.
Since I've been here, I've been very grateful that there's been a solidified plan of what I'm going to be doing.
I take vocal lessons from an Army sergeant first class.
And then my curriculum is kind of built off of the Navy Vocalist curriculum with a few adjustments
that are tailored to Marine Corps. Life in what the Marine Corps band will actually need from a fleet vocalist.
I'm so excited to help grow this M.O.S. I'm excited that more people are finding out about it
and that more people are going to come in and make this whole group that I get to work with.
I'm going to be really excited when this grows and solidifies itself.

youtube_description:
Lance Cpl. Megan Browning tells her story of going through the Naval School of Music in Norfolk, Virginia. She is the first Marine to be recruited as a vocalist. The Marine Corps created the vocalist Military Occupational Specialty in 2018 to fill the need for the specialized skillset it takes to be a singer. 

(U.S. Marine Corps video by Cpl. Benjamin Witten)
youtube_title: New Vocalist Job in the Marine Corps
